@October 12, 2023

Terminology

  • Business Intelligence → Analyse massive amounts of data with various tools for business purposes, is less complex and sophisticated than Data Mining.
  • Analytics → Learn to draw specific conclusions from the observation of raw data, mainly interested in decisions.
  • Data Mining → The entire discovery process sets up a pipeline starting from the data and ending with the general patterns and their translation into useful actions
  • Machine Learning → The application of methods and algorithms to extract the patterns from the data
  • Data Science → A broader term including data mining and Analytics, Business Intelligence, Machine Learning
  • Actionable knowledge → knowledge i can use to improve something

@October 18, 2023

General POV

  • Supervised Learning: we have a specific target to predict
    • Classification: works with countable number of possible outcomes
    • Regression: works with uncountable number of possible outcomes
  • Unsupervised Learning: we don’t have a specific target to predict
    • Clustering: understand natural subgroups in a group of individuals
    • Dimensionality reduction:
    PS: We think the data as a matrix, where the row (N) is the individual and the columns (D) are the dimensions which tell us about the complexity of the data and describes with data the individual.

There are cases where deep learning is not the best solution, maybe because i need large dataset and i will develop complex models.

Data Types

The possible data we can have and

and their possible transformations

@October 19, 2023

We need to consider that in each column we have a domain of allowed values and its cardinality.

  • Nominal, Ordinal → Discrete domain (maybe binary)
  • Interval, Ratio → Continuous domain

General characteristics of data set

  1. Dimensionality: the number of columns (curse of dimensionality)
  1. Sparsity: the numerous presence of zeros/nulls
  1. Beware the nulls in disguise: when missing values are not explicitly labeled as such or may be masked by other values, making it challenging to identify and handle them effectively.
  1. Resolution: the precision of our analysis
    (too precise→too affectable ; too general→too ineffective)

Data quality

There are indicators of bad data quality:

  • Noise → modification of original values
  • Outliers → data whose characteristics are considerably different from most of the data in the dataset
  • Missing values → we can ignore or estimate (by default or probability) them
  • Duplicates
  • Inconsistency

@October 25, 2023

Classification

Unsupervised classification

It exists but we don’t consider it, we will always talk about classification as supervised classification.

Supervised classification

Dataset (X) contains N individuals described by D attributes.

The label vector (Y) contains, for each individual (x), the class value (y).

C is the set of different labels y.

We want to learn the classification model y(x)

Classification model

It has to be parametrized in order to choose the most optimized option for our specific solution.

  • Decision function

    Given element x whose unknown class is y(x), makes a prediction by the classifier M(x,θ)=y(x)predM(x,\theta)=y(x)_{pred}M(x,θ)=y(x)pred​﻿ , where θ\thetaθ﻿ is the set of values of the parameters.
  • Learning process

    For a given classifier/model M(.,.)M(.,.)M(.,.)﻿, and for the dataset X and supervised labels Y, it determines θ\thetaθ﻿ in order to reduce the prediction error.

All the classifications have problems/errors but they have power to shatter the dataset
into subsets with homogeneous classes.

Classifier may assign to each individual one label (Crisp approach) or a probability for each of the possible labels (Probabilistic approach).

Vapnik-Chervonenkis Dimension

Therorem about the shattering power of a classification model (binary case for semplicity).

It says that with NNN﻿ elements there are 2N2^N2N﻿ possible different learning problems. If the model M(.,.)M(.,.)M(.,.)﻿ is able to shatter them all we say that it has Vapnik-Chervonenkis Dimension equal to N.

Classification workflow

  1. Learn the model for the given Y
    1. Have a training set with individuals and their label (ground truth)
    1. The training set should be representative as mush as possible
  1. Estimate the accuracy of the model
    1. Have a test set with known labels, and both were not used in training.
    1. The model is run by classification algorithm and assigns labels to test-individuals.
    1. Labels obtained are compared to test-labels to estimate accuracy.
  1. Use the model for new individuals

Decision Trees

A run–time classifier structured as a tree with inner nodes and leaf nodes.

In order to explorate the dataset, we have different graphs such as boxplots, histograms and pairplots.

  • BoxPlots
  • Histograms

    Quello che conosciamo già

  • PairPlots
    • Diagonal: displays histograms or kernel density plots of individual variables. These histograms provide insight into the univariate distribution of each variable.
    • Off-Diagonal: shows scatterplots representing two-dimensional relationships between pairs of variables.

Entropy

In information theory, entropy is a measure of the uncertainty or randomness associated with a random variable. It quantifies the amount of information needed to describe the outcome of a random variable.

  • HP

    P(v1)=p1,...,P(vv)=pvP(v_1)=p_1, ..., P(v_v)=p_vP(v1​)=p1​,...,P(vv​)=pv​﻿ → Given different values with different probabilities.

  • TH

    H(X)=−∑jpjlog2(pj)H(X)=-\sum_j{p_jlog_2(p_j)}H(X)=−∑j​pj​log2​(pj​)﻿
    The best coding allows the transmission with an average number of bits given by the entropy H of the source X.

  • H >> → probabilities are mostly similar
  • H << → some symbols have much higher probability
  • higher number of allowed symbols (distinct values in an attribute) gives higher entropy

@October 26, 2023

Entropy information gain

If we split the dataset, the entropy changes and becomes the the weighted sum of the entropies of the two parts.

  • HP

    Let d,t∈Dd,t \in Dd,t∈D﻿ and let c be the class attribute

  • TH:

    H(c∣d:t)=H(c∣d<t)∗P(d<t)+H(c∣d≥t)∗P(d≥t)H(c|d:t)=H(c|d<t)*P(d<t)+H(c|d\ge t)*P(d\ge t)H(c∣d:t)=H(c∣d<t)∗P(d<t)+H(c∣d≥t)∗P(d≥t)﻿

This the entropy of ccc﻿ with respect to ddd﻿.

When we have a the reduction of the entropy of a target class obtained with a split of the dataset. After the split, i obtain 2 subsets which are more pure.

The information gain is measured as IG(c∣d:t)=H(c)−H(c∣d:t)IG(c|d:t)=H(c)-H(c|d:t)IG(c∣d:t)=H(c)−H(c∣d:t)﻿, the difference of entropy before and after the cut. We define IG(c∣d)=maxtIG(c∣d:t)IG(c|d)=max_t{IG(c|d:t)}IG(c∣d)=maxt​IG(c∣d:t)﻿.

The change of threshold finds the best split.

So we must test the attribute which guarantees the maximum IG for the class attribute in the current data set X. Then we will partition X according to the outcome and reapply everything on the partitioned dataset.

Node structure

  • Then we continue with the right-leaf by recursion

PS: Weighted sum of the entropy of the descendant nodes is always smaller than the entropy in the ancestor node.

Recursion ends if we have 3 situations:

  1. We have a pure leaf.
  1. We have a not-pure leaf but we can’t purify it anymore, so we label it with majority class or one of the non-empty classes.
  1. We have an error rate as 1.35%, which is the lower limit error.

Pseudo-code for building a Decision Tree with binary splits

procedure buildTree(dataset X, node p) 
	if all the class values of X are c then
		return node p as a leaf, label of p is c

	if no attribute can give a positive information gain in X then say that the majority of elements in X has class c
		return node p as a leaf, label of p is c

find the attribute d and threshold t giving maximum information gain in X 

create two internal nodes descendant of p, say pleft and pright

let X_left = selection on X with d < t
buildTree(X_left, p_left)

let X_right = selection on sdata with d >= t 
buildTree(X_right, p_right)

Error (Training set VS Testing set)

  • Training set error

    This is the error or loss calculated on the training set. It measures how well the model fits the training data. A low training error indicates that the model has learned the patterns in the training data well.
  • Testing set error

    This is the error or loss calculated on the testing set. It measures how well the model generalizes to new, unseen data. The goal is to have a low testing error, indicating that the model can make accurate predictions on data it hasn't seen before.

Overfitting

When a learning algorithm is affected by noise, the performance on the test set is (much) worse than that on the training set.
  • HP

    Given hypothesis hhh﻿, error of the hypothesis on the training set errortrain(h)error_{train}(h)errortrain​(h)﻿ and error of the hypothesis on the entire dataset errorX(h)error_{X}(h)errorX​(h)﻿

  • TH

    hhh﻿ overfits the training set if there is h′h'h′﻿ such that {errortrain(h)<errortrain(h′)errorX(h)>errorX(h′)\begin{cases} error_{train}(h)<error_{train}(h')\\ error_{X}(h)>error_{X}(h') \end{cases}{errortrain​(h)<errortrain​(h′)errorX​(h)>errorX​(h′)​﻿

It may be caused by the presence of noise or the lack of representative instances.

Hyperparameters VS Parameters

Parameters are internal variables learned by the model during training, while hyperparameters are external configuration settings that are set prior to training. Parameters capture the specific patterns in the training data, whereas hyperparameters influence the learning process and overall model structure.

Impurity functions

We look for generating the maximum purity/impurity by the split and to do so we need to measure the purity of a node. In general we can say that the more classes are in a node and the less pure it is, but there are also other ways:

  1. Entropy

    The higher the entropy in the node and the lees pure the node is.
  1. Gini Index (default)
  1. Misclassification Error (optional) → SKIPPED

Gini Index

It is the total probability of wrong classification in a node with CjC_jCj​﻿ classes, and is measured as GINI(p)=1−∑jfp,j2GINI(p)=1-\sum_jf^2_{p,j}GINI(p)=1−∑j​fp,j2​﻿

  • Demonstration and details
    • fp,jf_{p,j}fp,j​﻿ is the frequency of the class j in the node p
    • fp,j∗(1−fp,j)f_{p,j}*(1-f_{p,j})fp,j​∗(1−fp,j​)﻿ is the probability of wrong assignment

We can deduce that GINI(p)∈[0;1−1/Cp]GINI(p)\in [0;1-1/C_p]GINI(p)∈[0;1−1/Cp​]﻿

When we have to split, we would divide the node ppp﻿ in dsdsds﻿ child nodes (p1,...,pdsp_1, ..., p_{ds}p1​,...,pds​﻿). The node has NpN_pNp​﻿ records while each child node will have Np,iN_{p,i}Np,i​﻿.

Then we compute the Gini Index of the future split as:

It was noticed that the Entropy is less sensitive to noise than Gini Index because of the , but in practice it depends.

  • Why maximising IG and GINI should be in general better than Missclassification Error?

    The missclassification error is just counting the number of good predictions in a node. So, In the multi-class problems, it doesn’t consider the proportions of minority classes.

@November 8, 2023

Complexity of Decision Tree Induction

The dataset is X=N∗DX=N*DX=N∗D﻿ and in the best case (each node diveded in 2 equal parts) we have a tree height O(log2N)O(log_2N)O(log2​N)﻿.

The worst case, in which every split creates a node with 1 element and the other with all other elements, has a depth of N−1N-1N−1﻿.

For each node, the algorithm needs to evaluate all features and thresholds to find the best split. The cost of evaluating a split is O(D∗log2N)O(D*log_2N)O(D∗log2​N)﻿ because of the operations it envolves.

If we count the cost for each node, the overall cost, it will be O(N∗D∗log2N)O(N*D*log_2N)O(N∗D∗log2​N)﻿, more than linear but less than quadratic.

Characteristics of Decision Tree Induction

  • Non-parametric approach, doesn’t require any assumption on the probability distributions of classes and attribute values.
  • Finding the best Decision Tree is NP-complete, problems are a class of decision problems for which no known efficient algorithm exists to find an exact solution and if it were found, it would work in nondeterministic polynomial time. So we use the heuristic algorithms to find sub–optimal solutions in reasonable times.
  • The run–time use of a Decision Tree to classify new instances is extremely efficient, O(h)O(h)O(h)﻿.
  • They are robust with respect to noise in the training set.
  • It can’t work with missing values, they will not be noticed otherwise (we add a new step to check this).
  • Redundant attribute (2+ attributes bring the same knowledge) are not a problem.
  • The deeper we go with pruning and the more irrelevant the last nodes become, due to the low number of training records they cover.
  • In practice, the impurity measure has low impact on the final result.
    Different impurity measures often lead to similar outcomes, indicating that the algorithm prioritizes creating nodes with distinct class assignments irrespective of the specific measure chosen. Moreover, the influence of other factors, such as hyperparameters and pruning strategy, tends to overshadow the nuanced impact of the impurity measure in real-world scenarios.
  • In practice, the pruning strategy has high impact on the final result
    Thanks to its pivotal role in preventing overfitting, promoting model generalization, and determining the overall trade-off between fit and complexity. Decisions regarding pruning directly shape the final outcome of the decision tree, making the strategy a critical factor for achieving optimal performance in real-world applications.

Conclusions

DT are easy to understand, implement and use. They control well overfitting (control tree depth).

  • Why do we prefer greedy algorithms instead of trying all the possible trees?

    Because they can lower the computational effort, still guaranteeing decent performances

Model Selection

It’s an essential part in ML. We have several options for writing/configuring a learner and we can choose between several models and for each model we can choose hyperparameters.

Finding the best model with the best configuration of hyperparameters, miximising the performance for a specific dataset.

Learning and Evaluating

Empirically the more data we have and the better performance we expect, but we need to measure how well the theory (model) fits the data and the cost generated by prediction errors.

We use the test error for this purpose, the evaluation can be general (all the nodes) or local (in a single node). So we obtain a test set error ratio xxx﻿, but we must also consider a runt-time error, in this way we are considering a confidence interval. confidence_interval=x  ±  ???confidence\_interval= x\ \ \pm \ \ ???confidence_interval=x  ±  ???﻿

Empirical frequency VS True frequency of error

  • Empirical frequency of error f=S/Nf=S/Nf=S/N﻿
    • S: numbers of errors observed
    • N: the total number of observations or trials

Because of noise, we have an unknown deviation from fff﻿ to the true frequency.

We assume noise to be normal distributed for N≥30N \ge 30N≥30﻿ .

Then we choose the confidence level, the probability that the true frequency of success is below the pessimistic frequency that we will compute.

  • Explanation

    The parameters are:

    • ppp﻿ → the true frequency of error
    • α\alphaα﻿ → tax of error (the complementar is tax of success)
    • zα/2z_{\alpha/2}zα/2​﻿ → critical value

    This parameterized equation says that the probability of the test to be in the confidence interval [zα/2  ;  z1−α/2][z_{\alpha/2} \ \ ; \ \ z_{1-\alpha/2}][zα/2​  ;  z1−α/2​]﻿ is the confidence level 1−α1-\alpha1−α﻿ .

    The test is represented with f−pp(1−p)/N\frac{f-p}{\sqrt{p(1-p)/N}}p(1−p)/N​f−p​﻿ is the standardized test statistic is therefore the difference between the observed frequency and the hypothesized proportion, standardized by the standard deviation of the proportion.

Range error estimate

With some transformation we may say that the range error estimate is

Where we have a pessimistic estimate if we chose +++﻿ or an optimistic one otherwise.

From this formula we can deduce that:

  1. The bigger NNN﻿ is and the smaller is the uncertainty.
  1. The more demanding we are and the bigger will be the uncertainty.

C4.5 strategy

  1. Consider a subtree near the leaves.
  1. Compute its maximum error eie_iei​﻿ as a weighted sum of the maximum error of the leaves.
  1. Compute the maximum error ere_rer​﻿ of the root of the subtree transformed into a leaf.
  1. Prune if er≤eie_r \le e_ier​≤ei​﻿ .
  1. With pruning, the error frequency increases, but the number of records in node also increases, therefore the maximum error can decrease.
  • Example
    1. Look at n12 → consider n121, n122
    1. ei=N121∗emax121+N122∗emax122e_i=N_{121}*emax_{121}+N_{122}*emax_{122}ei​=N121​∗emax121​+N122​∗emax122​﻿
    1. er=(N121+N122)∗emax12e_r=(N_{121}+N_{122})*emax_{12}er​=(N121​+N122​)∗emax12​﻿
    1. Prune

Pruning techniques

  • max_depth
    Horizontal cut below a given depth, removes all the branaches below
  • min_samples_split
    If a node has less than minimum number of samples i don’t split (default is 2)
  • min_samples_leaf
    The minimum number of samples to be a leaf node
  • min_impurity_decresae

    The node will be split if it introduces an impurity decrease ≥ given value.

Accuracy of a classifier

We need to measure the accuracy in order to compare classifiers.

For simplicity, we will use the empirical error frequencies, but in real cases the maximum error frequencies should be used instead.

For each model, in order to optimize it, we need to tune the hyperparameters.

Testing strategies

  1. Holdout
  1. Crossvalidation
  1. Leave one out
  1. Boostrap

Holdout

If the supervised data is too small, the training will be too small (N<30 elements) and our functions will not be valid anymore.

There are 2 alternatives:

  • Train and test

    The dataset is split into two subsets: a training set and a testing set. The model is trained on the training set and evaluated on the testing set.

  • Train, validate and test

    We have a bunch of different parameters settings. We train and validate, change the settings and then train and validate and change the settings ecc. After this loop we find the settings guaranteeing the best performance and with this configuration we test.

    ✅ It’s faster than the Cross Validation

    ✅ More reliable than the simple holdout, optimisation of the hyperparameters is done with the validation set, independent from the final evaluation.

    🚫 Less reliable with respect to Cross Validation, test is done on a portion of the examples

Crossvalidation

The training set is randomly partitioned into k subsets, then we make k iterations using one of the subsets for test and the others for training. In the end we combine the results of tests, the final performance will be the average performances obtained in each step.

✅ Optimal use of supervised data, each record is used k-1 times for training and once for testing

✅ More reliablity, estimate of the performance is averaged on k runs

🚫 The train/test loop is repeated k times

Leave one out

It’s a cross-validation with k=Nk=Nk=N﻿, so a partition for each element, so there is no random partitioning.

Bootstrap

It samples N records with replacement, so each record can be selectend even if it has been selected in previous samples.

Performance measures of a classifier

In order to give an idea, let’s see Binary prediction.

Performance indicators

The performance indicators may be:

  • Accuracy
  • Velocity
  • Robustness to noise
  • Scalability
  • Interpretability

Summary of measures

  1. Precision
    Precision is the ratio of correctly predicted positive observations to the total predicted positives. It measures the accuracy of positive predictions made by the model.
    Q:
    Of all instances predicted as positive, how many were actually positive?
  1. Recall
    Recall is the ratio of correctly predicted positive observations to the total actual positives. It measures the ability of the model to capture all the relevant instances.
    Q:
    Of all actual positive instances, how many were correctly predicted as positive?
  1. Specificity

    Specificity measures the ability of a classification model to correctly identify negative instances.
    Q:
    Of all actual negative instances, how many were correctly predicted as negative?
  1. F1-score

    The F1-Score is the harmonic mean of precision and recall. It provides a balance between precision and recall, especially when there is an uneven class distribution or when both false positives and false negatives are important. It is always interesting, because has higher values when precision and recall are reasonably balanced.
  1. Macro average (of measure fff﻿)
    We choose a measure and we compute the average over each result per class. They all have the same weight, so in some cases it may happen that the minority classes have influence bigger than their size.
  1. Weighted average (of measure fff﻿)

    It does the same as Macro average but use weights so that the measure of each class influences the result in proportion to its size.

Binary class case (Binary prediction)

We have 2 possible outcomes: True or False

The matrix we’ll fill is composed in this way:

We can find the TruePositive, FalseNegative, FalsePositive and TrueNegative comparing the true classe and the predicted class.

The accuracy/success rate will be TP+TNNtest\frac{TP+TN}{N_{test}}Ntest​TP+TN​﻿ and the error rate will be the complementar.

Precision: TPTP+FP\frac{TP}{TP+FP} TP+FPTP​﻿

Recall: TPTP+FN\frac{TP}{TP+FN} TP+FNTP​﻿

Specificity: TNTN+FP\frac{TN}{TN+FP} TN+FPTN​﻿

F1-score: F=2∗precision  ∗  recallprecision  +  recallF=2*\frac{precision \ \ * \ \ recall}{precision \ \ + \ \ recall}F=2∗precision  +  recallprecision  ∗  recall​﻿

Multi-class case

We need to generalise when there are more than 2 classes.

The matrix we’ll fill is composed in this way:

TxT_xTx​﻿→ true number for class x

PxP_xPx​﻿→ total number of predictions for class x

TPxTP_xTPx​﻿→ true predictions for class x

FPi−jFP_{i-j}FPi−j​﻿→ number of false prediction for class i predicted as j

We find TruePositve only on the diagonal. We need also to implement the measures but they are defined for single classes. So we introduce other 2 measures, considering the measure fff﻿, the classes ci∈Cc_i \in Cci​∈C﻿ with frequency CiC_iCi​﻿ :

Macro average of fff﻿: f(ci)C\frac{f(c_i)}{C}Cf(ci​)​﻿

Weighted average of fff﻿: f(ci)∗CiC\frac{f(c_i)*C_i}{C}Cf(ci​)∗Ci​​﻿

Improvement kkk﻿

Given a classifier Cˉ\bar{C}Cˉ﻿, we considera a random classifier RCˉR_{\bar{C}}RCˉ​﻿ that produces the same proportions of classes by chance. We consider its trend as standard and we’ll measure the contribution of Cˉ\bar{C}Cˉ﻿ in relation to RCˉR_{\bar{C}}RCˉ​﻿ .

Then we use this consideration to measure the improvement of classifier with respect to the improvement of the perfect classifier by:

Probability of concordance

Pr(c)=TPa+TPb+TPcNPr(c)=\frac{TP_a+TP_b+TP_c}{N}Pr(c)=NTPa​+TPb​+TPc​​﻿

Probability of random condordance

Pr(r)=Ta∗Pa+Tb∗Pb+Tc∗PcN2Pr(r)=\frac{T_a*P_a+T_b*P_b+T_c*P_c}{N^2}Pr(r)=N2Ta​∗Pa​+Tb​∗Pb​+Tc​∗Pc​​﻿

Which are examples of how the probabilities are considered. Then we use them to compute the improvement.

We notice that k∈[−1  ;  1]k \in [-1 \ \ ; \ \ 1]k∈[−1  ;  1]﻿.

It will be negative if our predictor works worse than randomness. For positive values, in general they mean:

Cost of errors

Every bad decision imply a cost we have to consider, there are 2 ways:

  1. Alterate proportions

    Duplicating the exaples for which the classification error is higher. The classifier become more able to classify the mistaken classifications. This becomes useful especially in imbalanced classes.
  1. Adapt learning scheme

    We add weights to the instances in order to balance them. In DecisionTreeClassifier of Scikit-Learn You can either manually assign weights to each class using the class_weight hyperparameter or let the algorithm automatically balance the classes with an option like balance.

Evaluation of a probabilistic classifier

Decision trees make a prediction of the class label (crisp prediction) or they can produce a tuple of probabilities (probabilistic prediction).

Probabilities → Crisp

It’s common to extract a single value from a set of possible ones, it just depends on the number of classes:

  1. Binary case

    We have to set a treshold different from the 50% because of the cost of error. We’ll see List Chart.
  1. Multiclass case

    We choose the value with maximum probability

Lift Chart

We sort all the classified elements for decreasing probability of positive class. Then we make a chart with (x, y) = (sample size, positive in sample).

We se 2 lines:

  1. Classifier-Ranked Line

    Plots the number of positives obtained drawing a fraction of test data with decreasing probability.
  1. Random Choice Line

    Plots the number of positives obtained with a random choice of a sample of test data.

So the larger the area between the two curves, the better the classification model.

ROC Curve

ROC stands for Receiver-Operator Charateristics.

  • TN = blue + cyan = probability of a negative to be caught
  • FN = cyan = probability of a negative to be missed
  • FP = pink + purple = probability of a positive to be missed
  • TP = red + purple = probability of a positive to be caught

Let’s see the first image. On the x we have the signal (High, Low). The 2 peaks represent the clean signal but the true signal usually have noise added and it has a Gaussian distribution and the 2 distributions interfere.

If i measure a point in the intersection, i will find 2 results. So we need to move the threshold.

We can move it to the exact intersection, but if we move it to the left we’ll have more negatives recognised as positives and viceversa.

Let’s se the second image. To obtain it we consider each possible threshold in the first image and count the TP and FP and we draw a point in the second image. The graph we obtain is proportional to the dispersion, and the perfect discriminator is

It caches all the true positives and then completes.

It is impossible and for our implementations we have to consider tradeoffs with respect to necessities and costs.

So the soft classifier can be converted in a crisp classifier by choosing a threshold, then we variate it and see de changes it involves in order to select the better shape.

Specifcally:

  1. sort the test elements by decreasing positive probability
  1. set the threshold to the highest probability, set TP and FP to zero
  1. Iterative part
    1. update the number of TP and FP with probability from the threshold to 1
    1. draw a point in the curve
    1. move to next top probability of positive

Naive Bayes Classifier

When we acquire some knowledge about (for example) the value of an attribute, we also can consider some posterior probability (es. we can assume better in which year you graduated if we know when you were born).

The Bayes Theorem puts in relation prior probability and posterior probability.

We can build a classifier on this theorem, assuming that each attribute is independent from the others, given the class (this simplification is why it’s called ‘Naive’, in reality attribute often are dependent).

Bayes’ Theorem

We assume the attributes as independent.
  • HP

    Hypothesis HHH﻿ and evidence EEE﻿ that bears on that hypothesis

  • TH

    In our case, the hypothesis is the class ccc﻿ the evidence are the values to be classified E=E1,...,ENE=E_1, ..., E_NE=E1​,...,EN​﻿. So, thanks to independence, we can se the formula in this way:

Why does this multiplication should be easier or reliable ?

In principle, i consider the supervised set and filter on a class and compute the probability of the entire couple.

If we thin carefully, we work with very large number of attributes with many possible values. So if we think to every possible couples of values we have to consider every combination and so a much more number, as a consequence we would see that the probability of each couple with respect to all the possible ones would be a very small number.

This means high risk of noise, small representativity, random effects and so unerliable.

Using the multiplication we consider the single attributes and their possible values, which increments considerably the order of magnitude, this strongly limits the problems seen previously.

Laplace Smoothing

There is a value that in multiplication, the value 0 makes the probability of the class drops to 0 and the other attributes don’t mean anything.

So we need to smooth the 0, in order to still consider the meaning of the value in the attribute but also preserve the meaning of the entire dataset.

So the smoothed frequency is:

  • Where
    • α\alphaα﻿ is the smoothing parameter
    • afd=vi,caf_{d=v_i,c}afd=vi​,c​﻿ is the absolute frequency of value viv_ivi​﻿ in attribute ddd﻿ over class ccc﻿
    • VVV﻿ number of distinct values in attribute ddd﻿
    • afcaf_cafc​﻿ is the absolute frequency of class ccc﻿

We can notice that

  1. if α=0\alpha = 0α=0﻿ then sfd=vi,c=afd=v1,cafcsf_{d=v_i,c}=\frac{af_{d=v_1,c}}{af_c}sfd=vi​,c​=afc​afd=v1​,c​​﻿ we obtain the standard formula
  1. if α→∞\alpha \rightarrow \infty α→∞﻿ then sfd=vi,c=1Vsf_{d=v_i,c}=\frac{1}{V}sfd=vi​,c​=V1​﻿ we obtain the absolute frequency

Missing values

They do not affect the model.

  • In testing

    Calculation of the likelyhood simply omits this attribute and it will be higher for all the classes, but this is compensated by the normalization.
  • In training

    The record is simply not included in the frequency counts for that attribute.

Numeric value

With real numbers, the frequency method is inapplicable, those value are more dense and probabilities will become to small.

We assume that the values have a Gaussian distribution.

Classification with Linear Perceptron

Linear Perceptron

It was invented to be similar to human brain, in fact it is called artificial neuron and it works to give an output from a linear combination of weight wiw_iwi​﻿ applied to inputs did_idi​﻿.

Hyperplane

If we have a numeric dataset, we can find an hyperplane such that we have all the positives (+) on one side and the negatives (-) on the other side.

We can’t always find it

The hyperplane is described by a set of weights w0,...,wDw_0, . . . ,w_Dw0​,...,wD​﻿ in a
linear equation on the data attributes
x0,...,xDx_0, . . . , x_Dx0​,...,xD​﻿ .

So there are none or infinte hyperplanes that can be described as

But we need to find at least 1 hyperplane if it exists and the procedure is:

The algorithm initializes weights to zero and iteratively updates them while there are misclassifications. For each training instance, if it is misclassified, the algorithm adjusts the weights based on the class of the instance by adding the data vector to the weights if the class is positive, and subtracting it if the class is negative. This process continues until no misclassifications remain. The algorithm essentially learns from errors, updating weights to improve classification accuracy over successive iterations, making it suitable for binary classification tasks.

Le’s go in the details to see why it is working.

  • Linear perceptron convergence

    Each change of weights move the hyperplane, for example let’s add an instance xxx﻿.

    We can notice that the orignal amount increases/decreases by a positive amount x02+...+xD2x_0^2 +...+ x_D^2x02​+...+xD2​﻿ .

    • If we have a positive instance classified as negative we’ll choose +++﻿, to have a more positive result in order to classify it better.
    • If we have a negative instance classified as positive we’ll choose −-−﻿ , to have a more negative result in order to classify it better.

If the dataset is not linearly separable, the algorithm won’t terminate and for this is important to set an upper bound to the iterations.

Computational Complexity

It is O(N∗D)O(N*D)O(N∗D)﻿ .

Support Vector Machines (SVM)

We have seen the problem of the linear perceptron if the data are not linearly separable. We can give up the linearity with exponential coefficient but we would have an increment of the number of variables and it would become intractable soon and would prone to overfitting.

Maximum Margin Hyperplane

We have seen that may be 1 or infinite hyperplanes, but if there are multiple ones we can identify some as better than the others.

To do so we define the margin, the distance between the separating hyperplanes and the 2 nearest examples on the opposite sides.

The best hyperplane will be the one with the largest margin, because it will be more solid in front of noise and so it would probably guarantee a better classification than others.

In this case B1B_1B1​﻿ is better than B2B_2B2​﻿ .

If the dataset is linearly separable, the data don’t intersect and so we can define the convex hull.

It is the tightest enclosing convex polygon which contains all the points of the same set.

The perimeter of the polygon will be traced by connecting the outermost data points, and these will be called support vectors.

Those are useful to better define the problem.

In reality is quite common not to find a perfect hyperplane, so it’s necessary to find a compromise, a soft hyperplane, than almost separates the classes

In order to implement the softness of hyperplane, we define a penalty parameter CCC﻿ to be tuned.

Non-linear class boundaries

In the space we can overcome the absence of linear hyperplane by finding non linear ones. We can so add dimensions and map the data in a new space (feature space) in order to find a linear mapping there.

The increase of dimensions requires ‘dot product computations’ in the training vectors. In order to avoid the increment of complexity we use kernel functions.

  • Some kernel functions
    • Linear: K(x,y)=xTyK(x, y) = x^T yK(x,y)=xTy﻿
    • Polynomial: K(x,y)=(xx+x1y−r)dK(x, y) = (xx + x_1y - r)^dK(x,y)=(xx+x1​y−r)d﻿
    • RBF: K(x,y)=exp⁡(−γ∥x−y∥2)K(x, y) = \exp\left(-\gamma \|x - y\|^2\right)K(x,y)=exp(−γ∥x−y∥2)﻿
    • Sigmoid: K(x,y)=tanh⁡(αxTy+c)K(x, y) = \tanh(\alpha x^T y + c)K(x,y)=tanh(αxTy+c)﻿

Computational Complexity

It strongly depends on the implementations, the popular library libSVM scales from O(D∗N2)O(D*N^2)O(D∗N2)﻿ to O(D∗N3)O(D*N^3)O(D∗N3)﻿ depending on data caching.

Neural Networks

They arrange many perceptrons together as neurons are arranged in animal brains. In fact neurons act like a signal processor with a threshold and weight.

The functions used to describe them are continuous, differentable, superiorly and inferiorly limited and don’t have to be linear.

This mean that in generalf(x1+x2)≠f(x1)+f(x2)f(x_1+x_2) \ne f(x_1) + f(x_2) f(x1​+x2​)=f(x1​)+f(x2​)﻿, this is important to reduce the effect of noise because it means that error in input doesn’t grow linearly and so, positioning non-linear curve in proximity of certain points were most probably will have noise, we can reduce it.

This is an example of how these shapes works in presence of value with noise which would be difficult to classify, see how the error tends to be mitigated.

PS: in this example is important to consider that it applies the shape various times in sequence.

Feed–forward multi–layered network

We say multi-layered because there are 3 layers (input, hidden, output).

  • Input
    one input node for each dimension in the training set, feeds the hidden layer.
  • Hidden
    the number of nodes in the hidden layer are a parameter of the network, feeds the output layer. It elaborates the input
    eie_iei​﻿ as the transfer function ( sigmoid or sgm(.)sgm(.)sgm(.)﻿ ) of the linear combination of inputs and their weights wj,iw_{j,i}wj,i​﻿ .


    vj=sgm(∑i=0n_inputswj,i∗ei)v_j=sgm(\sum_{i=0}^{n\_inputs}{w_{j,i}*e_i})vj​=sgm(∑i=0n_inputs​wj,i​∗ei​)﻿ for j∈[0  ;  n_inputs]j \in [0 \ \ ; \ \ n\_inputs]j∈[0  ;  n_inputs]﻿


    sgm(x)=11+e−xsgm(x) = \frac{1}{1+e^{-x}}sgm(x)=1+e−x1​﻿ ps: sgm(x)∈  ]0;1[sgm(x) \in \ \ ]0 ;1[sgm(x)∈  ]0;1[﻿

  • Output
    the number of nodes in the output layer is related to number of different classes in the domain.

We say feed-forward because the information flows from Input to Output (i may also have feedbacks ) and gets elaborated in each node as a transfer function of the linear combination of the input of the node and the weights.

My configuration of weights give me some error. In order to reduce the error we can find the error functions and find the gradient by computing the derivatives with respect to weights. Plotting them i could find convex (1 pt. minimum) and non-convex (multiple pts. minimum) functions.

Training a Neural Network

The algorithm initializes a neural network with random weights.

It enters a loop, repeatedly processing each training instance. For each instance xxx﻿ , the network computes an output and calculates weight corrections based on the difference between the output nn(x)nn(x)nn(x)﻿ and the expected result xOutx_{Out}xOut​﻿ (ground truth).

These corrections are then propagated backward through the network.

After processing all instances, the algorithm checks a termination condition. If not satisfied, the loop continues; otherwise, the algorithm concludes.

This process iterates until the termination condition is met, refining the network's weights to improve its performance.

In this way, iteration after iteration, we obtain that the weights encode better and better the knowledge.

The convergence is not guaranteed, so we would force the termination after some time or maybe we would use a threshold for errors.

There is also a parameter called learning rate. It reduces the amount of corrections that we apply to weights. We assume that iteration after iteration we are nearer and nearer to the optimal solution and so we assume that we start with many corrections to apply but then, correction after correction, we have fewer and fewer corrections to apply. So we start with a large learning rate (many things to do) and we end with a short one (have nothing to do).

We standardize the training set ∼N(0,1)\sim \mathcal{N}(0,1)∼N(0,1)﻿

Computing weight corrections

  • Error function

    E(w)=(y−Transfer(w,x))22E(w)=\frac{(y-Transfer(w,x))^2}{2}E(w)=2(y−Transfer(w,x))2​﻿ (quadratic definition, there are other alternatives)

    Where:

    • ww w﻿ is the input weight of a node
    • xx x﻿ is the input vector
    • yyy﻿ is the desider output of a node
  • Gradient

    We want the www﻿ that minimizes the error. So we need to compute the gradient

    ddxsgm(x)=e−x(1+e−x)2=(1−sgm(x))∗sgm(x)\frac{d}{dx} sgm(x) = \frac{e^{-x}}{(1+e^{-x})^2}=(1-sgm(x))*sgm(x) dxd​sgm(x)=(1+e−x)2e−x​=(1−sgm(x))∗sgm(x)﻿

    The derivatives become much complex (we didn’t go deep here), but their computation provides the weight corrections which will be backpropagated.

Learning

There are different strategies for learning:

  1. Stochastic
    Each forward propagation is followed by a weight update, extremely greedy algorithm, introduce more noise.
  1. Batch
    We have many propagation and then a single weight update, it accumulates errors and so it’s more stable.
A repetition around all the samples is called epoch.

  • Design Choice
    1. structure of inputs/outputs
    1. number of nodes in hidden layer
    1. The different learning rate in different epochs (starts high and ends low)

  • Risks

So we have to choose:

K Nearest Neighbours Classifier

The model is the entire training set. When we have to use it to classify an item, we compare it with the training set and we look for the nearest ones.

So we pick KKK﻿ entries from the database which are similar to the item we have to classify and between the labels of the entries we choose the one which appears more frequently.

  1. KK K﻿, in order to know how many neighbours the algorithm must consider
  1. metric, which changes the definition of distance between points and so changes the base on which we choose neighbours.
    (Euclidean distance ≠ Manhattan distance ≠ Mahalanobis distance)

(Binary → Multi-class) classifier

Some algorithms are inherently binary oriente such as multi linear perceptron and SVC.

It’s not easy to face this problem, as we would have to extract more informations from fewer informations. There are 2 ways to handle:

  1. Transform algorithm and model → expensive
  1. Use more binary-classifiers and combine results
    1. OVO (1v1)
    1. OVR (1vN)

OVO (One-vs-One)

If i have CCC﻿ classes, i can consider all the possible pairs of them and generate a binary-classifier for each of them (there are C(C−1)2\frac{C(C-1)}{2}2C(C−1)​﻿ pairs), then the classifiers give a vote on an unknown instance and those votes are aggregate to extract the result.

Then we have to apply a voting scheme, so we take the previous results and decide how to give points to the possible classes. In the end, the class with more points wins and gets assigned to the instance.

OVR (One-vs-Rest)

If i have CCC﻿ classes, i can consider a classifier for each of them. We should prepare for each training a dataset where there is a class that stays untouched and the others.

Then we have to apply a voting scheme, we combine the confidences scores and the class with the highest global score wins.

OVO vs OVR

  • OVO requires too many classifiers:

    For CCC﻿ classes we’ll need C(C−1)2>>C\frac{C(C-1)}{2} >> C2C(C−1)​>>C﻿ , so we can say than we the same amount of classifiers we can solve smaller problems.
  • OVR tends to be more unbalances:

    For CCC﻿ classes, in our classifiers we’ll have a proportion of 111﻿ positive and C−1C-1C−1﻿ negatives.

Ensemble methods

The methods seen before work by using a set of base classifiers and they tend to perform better then single classifiers.

Performance

We can verify it by probability, in fact ( considering the errors independent ) we can compute the error of the set, given NN N﻿ binary classifiers and at least KK K﻿ of them are right:

And as you can see:

  • the more the base error is over to 50% of error and the more the ensemble error will grow to 100% .
  • the more the base error is less than 50% of error and the more the ensemble error will decrease to 0% .

Methods

We can resample the data:

  1. Training set
    1. Bagging
      Samples with replacement according to
      N(0,1)N(0,1)N(0,1)﻿ and simplyfies the complexity of the computation.
    1. Boosting
      Iteratively changes the distribution of training examples so that the base classifier focus on examples which are hard to classify. So we look into the result and if there are examples that hard to classify, the classifier will be stronger.
    1. Adaboost
      We select the base classifier in function according to its error rate.
  1. Input features
    1. Random Forest

      We choose several decison trees with less input features which are random/suggested subset of the real input parameters.
  1. Class labels

    This is useful when we have many labels.
    This approach transforms a high-dimensional multi-class classification problem into a set of binary classification problems through random partitioning of class labels, and then combines the predictions of binary classifiers during the testing phase to make a final decision.

Forest of randomized trees

We want to to create a diverse set of classifiers, particularly decision trees, by introducing randomness during their construction, thanks to the classifiers’ independence.

Each tree in the ensemble is built from a sample drawn with replacement from the training set (bootstrap sampling). Once the ensemble of trees is constructed, the prediction of the ensemble for a new instance is obtained by averaging the predictions of individual trees.

This helps to reduce overfitting and improve the generalization ability of the ensemble.

Tradeoff (Bias vs Variance)

  • Bias
    It’s the simplifying assumptions made by the model to make the target function easier to approximate.
    💡 High bias implies that the model is making strong assumptions about the data, possibly oversimplifying the underlying patterns. This can lead to systematic errors or inaccuracies in predictions.
  • Variance
    It’s the amount that the estimate of the target function will change, given different training data.
    💡High variance implies that the model is highly flexible and can adapt to different datasets. However, this flexibility may lead to overfitting, where the model captures noise in the training data rather than the true underlying patterns.

( Bias 📈 ; Variance 📉 ) ⇒ Oversimplified models → Consistent errors

( Bias 📉 ; Variance 📈 ) ⇒ Overcomplicated models → Potential overfitting

So we need to find a tradeoff that minimizes both.

Decision trees are characterized by high variance and so tend to overfit. In order to find the tradeoff, we want to inject randomness to find a balance.

Boosting

This strategy involves associating weights with training instances, training multiple classifiers based on these weights, and iteratively adjusting the weights to emphasize instances that are challenging for the ensemble. This iterative feedback loop aims to improve the ensemble's performance on difficult examples.

AdaBoost

AdaBoost begins by assigning equal weights to all training examples. It sequentially trains weak learners on the data, adjusting weights based on their performance. Emphasis is placed on incorrectly classified examples, increasing their weights, while correctly classified examples have reduced weights.

Weak learners focus on challenging instances, and their predictions are combined through a weighted vote. This iterative process continues, with each new learner refining the model's ability to handle difficult cases. The final prediction is a weighted combination of all learners, giving more influence to those that effectively correct errors.

Adaptive and iterative, AdaBoost dynamically adjusts to the complexity of the data, making it a powerful ensemble learning algorithm.

The more clear the separation (between red and blue) is and the better the algorithm is for that dataset in input.

Regression

How can we forecast a target that is not a label but a number?

We can imagine numbers like a set of infinite labels. Regression is usually the strategy we can adopt, it's a supervised task with numeric variables, with the objective of minimizing the error of the prediction with the respect to the target.

Given a dataset XXX﻿ with NNN﻿ x DDD﻿ dimension, we’ll have:

Response vector

yˉ=[y1y2⋮yN]\bar{y} = \begin{bmatrix} y_1 \\ y_2 \\ \vdots \\ y_N \end{bmatrix}yˉ​=​y1​y2​⋮yN​​​﻿

Vector of coefficients

w=[w1w2⋮wD]w = \begin{bmatrix} w_1 \\ w_2 \\ \vdots \\ w_D \end{bmatrix}w=​w1​w2​⋮wD​​​﻿

Such that:

yi≈wT∗xi∀i∈{1,…,N}y_i \approx w^T *x_i \quad \forall i \in \{1, \ldots, N\}yi​≈wT∗xi​∀i∈{1,…,N}﻿

Objective function

Also known as the loss function or cost function, is a measure that quantifies the difference between the predicted values of a model and the actual observed values in the dataset.

The goal of regression is to minimize this objective function, which essentially represents the error or discrepancy between the predicted and actual values.

In order to minimize it, we have to compute the gradient and put it to zero in order to find the parameters www﻿ that minimize the error.

Quality of the fitting

We need to evaluate the quality of the regression and for this reason we have the coefficient of determination.

It represents the proportion of the variance in the dependent variable that is predictable from the independent variables in a regression model. In other words, it quantifies the goodness of fit of the regression model. So, considering the mean of the observed data yˉ=1N∑iyi\bar y = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i} y_iyˉ​=N1​∑i​yi​﻿ , the coefficient of determination is the

Observations on R^2

  • R2=1R^2=1R2=1﻿ when the model is perfect
  • R2<0R^2<0R2<0﻿ when the model doesn't follow the data trend

Comparison (R^2 vs MSE)

Coefficient of determination

  • Refers to error of the predictions
  • Is a standardised index
  • Tells how well the predictor variables can explain the variation in the response variable
  • Is not meaningful for non–linear or non–algebraic regression models

Mean Squared Error

  • Refers to error of the predictions
  • Measures the mean error → influenced by the order of magnitude
  • Tells how well a regression model can predict the value of a response variable in absolute terms
  • Better for comparing the accuracy among different linear regression models

Fitting

The response variable depends by more than one features (Multiple regression).

In presence of a high number of features overfitting is possible, regularization reduces the influence of less interesting attributes and therefore reduces overfitting.

In polynomial regression the target is influenced by a single feature, the relationship cannot be described by a straight line, which would cause an underfitting problem.

Using higher degree polynomials may help fitting the training data but it may lead to an overfitting model, which was even difficult to calculate, so we need a trade-off between the extremes, finding a degree which helps us fitting the data without overfitting.

@November 23, 2023

The Data - Pre–processing and dissimilarities

We have seen many ways to pre-process data:

  1. Aggregation
  1. Sampling
  1. Dimensionality Reduction
  1. Feature subset selection
  1. Feature creation
  1. Discretization and Binarization Attribute Transformation

Aggregation

It’s the process of combining two or more attributes or objects into a single attribute or object.

It’s usefull for:

  1. Data reduction

    ⇒ We minimize the complexity of datasets by decreasing the number of attributes or objects.
    In complex datasets with numerous attributes or objects, combining them into a single entity helps streamline information, making it more manageable and facilitating easier analysis.
  1. Change of scale

    ⇒ We represent information at a different level of granularity.
    Grouping entities at a higher level of abstraction allows for a broader perspective, enabling the analysis of trends or patterns that may not be apparent when examining individual components.
  1. More stable data

    ⇒ We minimize variability and enhancing the stability of the dataset.
    Aggregated data tends to exhibit less fluctuation or variability compared to individual data points. By combining attributes or objects, the impact of outliers or random fluctuations can be mitigated.

Sampling

Obtaining the entire dataset is always expensive and time consuming, so quite often it’s used a sample that will work almost as well as using the entire data sets, if it is representative.

A sample is representative if it has approximately the same property (of interest) as the original set of data.

We may have different types of sampling:

  1. Simple random

    It’s a subset of a statistical population in which each member of the subset has an equal probability of being chosen. The selection is done entirely by chance.
    It’s done by generating the permutation of indexes of the dataset and taking a first part.
  1. With replacement

    It’s like repeating independent extractions in sequence. It’s simply done by remaking the extractions on the same set.
  1. Without replacement

    It’s like repeating dependent extractions in sequence, removing each time the extracted element from the population.
  1. Stratified
    The population is divided into subgroups or strata based on certain characteristics, and then random samples are taken independently from each stratum.

We have also to choose the optimal sample size in order not to lose too much information.

Then we must not forget that, if the number data elements is not big enough, it can be difficult to guarantee a stratified partitioning in train/test split or in cross–validation split.

Dimensionality reduction

It’s important to notice that may think that the higher the dimensionality and the more sparse the data are in the space, but here we would fall in the curse of dimensionality.

If we compute the variability of the distance maxd−mindmind\frac{max_d-min_d}{min_d}mind​maxd​−mind​​﻿ , comparing the maximum distance from a pair of point and the minimum one, as a function of the number of dimension, we’ll find out that the higher the dimensions and the more close the data are. So it’s now clear that distances become uneffective, also because of noise that becomes more dangerous if points are more close.

For this reason it’s important to consider the reduction of dimensions as they also reduce the curse of dimensionality, the noise, time and memory complexity and it makes the dataset easier to be visualized.

It may be performed by:

  • PCA (Principal Component Analysis)

    Completely unsupervised.

    We consider the covariance matrix and its eigenvectors (as many as the original dimension) which will define the new space. The new dataset will have the only attributes that capture most of the data variation.

  • SVD (Singular Value Decomposition) [not explained by prof]

    The idea is to decompose the dataset in 3 matrices X=UΣVTX=UΣV^TX=UΣVT﻿ which capture better the meaning of the dataset, then we reduce the 3 matrices to kkk﻿ elements and ricompose them to obtain a well reduce subset of the dataset.

    We can say that:

    • UUU﻿ captures the descending-ordered list of the most significant patterns
    • Σ ΣΣ﻿ captures in the diagonal the importance of each pattern
    • VTV^TVT﻿ provides the information about how specific features play a role in the overall appearance.
  • Supervised techniques [not explained by prof]

    Incorporate class labels or target variables in the process of selecting relevant features.

  • Non-linear techniques [not explained by prof]

    Aim to capture intricate patterns and structures in high-dimensional data that may not be apparent in a linear space.

To reduce the dimensionality, we have to try to loose less information as possible and so we need to perform a feature subset selection, for example removing redundant attributes or irrelevant attributes.

We may also choose the subset by:

  1. Brute force

    Tries all the possible feature subsets as input and measures the effectivness
  1. Embedded approach

    Some algorithms has in their nature a selection of some features (es. decision trees)
  1. Filter approach

    We may select some features before running the data mining algorithm, so we are applying a filter.
  1. Wrapper approaches

    Instead of exhaustively trying all possible subsets like in the brute-force method, a wrapper approach allows the algorithm itself to evaluate and select the most relevant features.

Data-type conversions

Many algorithms require numeric features, in order to use them we have to convert our type.

Nominal → Numeric

If we have a discrete attribute with VVV﻿ values, we can expand it in VVV﻿ attributes with binary value.

So in the dataset, instead of putting the discrete value, we’ll put a 111﻿ in the corrispective binary-column and V−1V-1V−1﻿ zeros in the others.

We may also use other tricks, for example if we have a scale of values, we can also use ordinal numbers.

In this example we’d better done Quality = (Awful, …, Great) = (0, …, 4)

  • Will the decision tree be influenced by the arbitrary assumptions that we are making ?

    NO, because it is only influences by the order of the value and not by the distances.

Python library: sklearn.preprocessing.OneHotEncoder

Ordinal → Numeric

By default is assumed lexicographic order but we can eventually specify it.

Python library: sklearn.preprocessing.OrdinalEncoder

Numeric → Binary

We simply put a threshold and just say:

Python library: sklearn.preprocessing.Binarizer

Continuous → Discrete

Given the data, i can discretize them in 3 ways:

  1. Equal width

    The range of the continuous variable is divided into equal-width intervals or bins, does not take in account the distribution of data.
    The
    algorithm is:
    1. Determine the minimum and maximum values of the variable.
    1. Decide on the number of bins (intervals) you want to create.
    1. Calculate the width of each bin by dividing the range by the number of bins.
    1. Assign each data point to the appropriate bin based on its value.
  1. Equal frequency

    The dataset is divided into bins such that each bin contains approximately the same number of data points.
    The
    algorithm is:
    1. Sort the values of the variable in ascending order.
    1. Determine the desired number of bins.
    1. Assign an equal number of data points to each bin.
  1. K-means

    The dataset is divided in group with similar (draw lines where there is more space) data points into k clusters based on their proximity to cluster centroids.

Python library: sklearn.preprocessing.KBinsDiscretizer

Similarity and Dissimilarity

  • Similarity → a numerical measure of how alike two data objects are.
  • Dissimilarity → numerical measure of how different two data objects are.

Euclidean distance L2L_2L2​﻿

Euclidean distance is calculated as the straight-line distance between two points in a multi-dimensional space.

  • Where
    • DDD﻿ is the number of dimensions
    • pdp_dpd​﻿ is the d-th attribute of ppp﻿
    • qdq_dqd​﻿ is the d-th attribute of qqq﻿

When the features have different scales, the contribution of features with larger scales to the distance calculation can dominate, leading to biased results.

So we’ll need to use Standardization/Rescaling.

Minkowski distance LrL_rLr​﻿

It’s a generalization of Euclidean distance.

  • Where
    • DDD﻿ is the number of dimensions
    • pdp_dpd​﻿ is the d-th attribute of ppp﻿
    • qdq_dqd​﻿ is the d-th attribute of qqq﻿
    • rrr﻿ is a parameter which is chosen depending on the data set and the
      application
  • Cases
    • r=1r=1r=1﻿ → Manhattan norm or ‘city block’ → betterm with small differences
    • r=2r=2r=2﻿ → Euclidean norm
    • r=∞r=\infinr=∞﻿ → Chebyshev norm → better with maximum differences

Mahalanobis distance

Doesn’t consider a dimension at a time, but the covariance among different dimensions.

In this way, even tho B and C are at the same geometrical distance from A, we will identify C as the more near (following the meaning of near=similar) because C follows better the direction of the dataset. So if we want a distance in order to measure the similarity, we’ll use that.

The distance will be:

Where the covariance matrix is composed:

We also have better remember that

  • Cov(x,x)=Var(x)Cov(x,x)=Var(x)Cov(x,x)=Var(x)﻿
  • Cov(x,y)≥0Cov(x,y)\ge0Cov(x,y)≥0﻿ if they both grow together
  • If the matrix is diagonal, the variables are non-correlated.
  • If the variables are standardized, the diagonal contains "one."
  • If the variables are standardized and non-correlated, the matrix is the identity matrix, and the Mahalanobis distance is the same as the Euclidean distance.

Common properties of a distance

  1. Positive definiteness

    dist(p,q)≥0  ∀p,qdist(p,q)=0    ⟺  p=qdist(p,q)\ge0 \ \ \forall p,q\\ dist(p,q)=0 \ \ \iff p=qdist(p,q)≥0  ∀p,qdist(p,q)=0  ⟺p=q﻿
  1. Symmetry

    dist(p,q)=dist(q,p)  ∀p,qdist(p,q)=dist(q,p) \ \ \forall p,q dist(p,q)=dist(q,p)  ∀p,q﻿
  1. Triangle inequality

    dist(p,q)≤dist(p,r)+dist(r,q)  ∀p,q,rdist(p, q) \le dist(p, r) + dist(r, q) \ \ \forall p, q, r dist(p,q)≤dist(p,r)+dist(r,q)  ∀p,q,r﻿

Correlation

If we want to measure the relationship between 2 pair of numerical attributes, the right procedure is to consider all the values of each attribute in 2 vectors ppp﻿ and qqq﻿ . Then we standardize them in p′p'p′﻿ and q′q'q′﻿ and finally we compute the correlation.

If we want to measure the relationship between 2 pair of nominal attributes, we have to consider entropy of the vectors in the simmetric uncertainty equation.

Imbalanced data in classification

There is the risk that our classification model doesn’t work well on minority classes. Most algorithms face this problem by using a class_weight parameter which changes the cost function. In practice uses oversampling on the same minority class to produce a better balanced training set. We don’t add knowledge.

On the other side is even possible the undersampling. We use it to reduce the weight of a majority class in order to balance the training set (we drop out informations).

We can also use data augmentation from examples of minority class in order to generate new random examples.

It works in this way:

  1. Take a random example of minority class
  1. See the kkk﻿ nearest neighbors
  1. From the neighbors, selects one of them and creates a point in the between.

🛑 Be careful to use the right workflow.
1) Resample the training set
2) Optimize the estimator
3) Test the estimator on the test set

Clustering

Given a dataset it’s normal to desire to divide it in various cluster of similar data. So we want a clustering function clust(x)clust(x)clust(x)﻿ so that:

Different clustering functions may classify differently the same points, so we need to choose between the possible function which will perform better in our dataset, but we have to choose the measurement.

Centroid

It’s a point in the clusters which have, as coordinates, the average of the coordinate of all the points in the dataset.

K-means

The algorithm bases on Euclidean Distance.

graph TD;

subgraph Initialization
  A[Ask user for K clusters]
  B[Randomly choose K points as centers]
end

subgraph Iteration
  C[Assign each point to its nearest center;  es. colour]
  D[Calculate centroid for each center]
  E[Move centers to the calculated centroids]
end

A --> B;
B --> C;
C --> D;
D --> E;
E --> C;
What are we trying to optimize ?

We want that, step after step, to minimize distortion. We’ll see that is not a viable solution to choose the clusters.

SSE will be 0 only if the data are the centroid (which is nearly impossible) or will decreases whit the increment of the number of centroids.

Moreover, the algorithm doesn’t take in account the innate disequilibrium of the dataset. So, for example, if a data is faraway from all the centroids, it will count it anyway and this will make less precise the value of the centroid it is assigned to and we cant’t make anything because it’s natural.

Distortion

We see the distortion as the difference between the real value of an information and the value which is received after the Encoding/Decoding procedure, the official name is SSE (Sum of Squared Errors).

  • HP
    • Dataset: {xi,i=1,...,N}\{x_i,i=1,...,N\}{xi​,i=1,...,N}﻿
    • Encode:RD→[1...K]Encode: {R}^D \rightarrow [1...K]Encode:RD→[1...K]﻿
    • Decode:[1...K]→RDDecode: [1...K] \rightarrow {R}^DDecode:[1...K]→RD﻿
  • TH

Minimal Distortion

So now we want to minimize the formula and so we want to understand the best values of c1,...,ckc_1,...,c_kc1​,...,ck​﻿ possible.

  1. xix_ixi​﻿ must be encoded with the nearest center, otherwise the distortion could be reduced by substituting Encode(xi)Encode(x_i)Encode(xi​)﻿ with the nearest center.

    cEncode(xi)=argmincj∈{c1,…,cK} (xi−cj)2c_{Encode(x_i)} = \underset{c_{j} \in \{c_{1}, \ldots, c_{K}\}}{\text{argmin}} \, (x_{i} - c_{j})^2cEncode(xi​)​=cj​∈{c1​,…,cK​}argmin​(xi​−cj​)2﻿
  1. Each center must be the centroid of the points it owns.



    Distortion=(1)∑i=1N(xi−cEncode(xi))2=(2)∑j=1K∑i∈OwnedBy(cj)(xi−cj)2\text{Distortion}=_{(1)}\sum_{i=1}^N(x_i-c_{Encode(x_i)})^2=_{(2)}\sum_{j=1}^K\sum_{i\in OwnedBy(c_j)}(x_i-c_j)^2\\Distortion=(1)​∑i=1N​(xi​−cEncode(xi​)​)2=(2)​∑j=1K​∑i∈OwnedBy(cj​)​(xi​−cj​)2﻿Where:
    (1) Is the definition of distortion
    (2) We generalize for all values of
    jjj﻿, so for each centroid cjc_jcj​﻿ and for every object encoded in that centroid.


    So now we want to extract the distortion introduced by the single centroid cjc_jcj​﻿ .



    ∂Distortion∂cj  =(3)  ∂∂cj∑i∈OwnedBy(cj)(xi−cj)2  =(4)  −2∑i∈OwnedBy(cj)(xi−cj)\frac{\partial \text{Distortion}}{\partial c_j}\ \ =_{(3)}\ \ \frac{\partial}{\partial c_j}\sum_{i\in OwnedBy(c_j)}(x_i-c_j)^2\ \ =_{(4)}\ \ -2\sum_{i\in OwnedBy(c_j)}(x_i-c_j)∂cj​∂Distortion​  =(3)​  ∂cj​∂​∑i∈OwnedBy(cj​)​(xi​−cj​)2  =(4)​  −2∑i∈OwnedBy(cj​)​(xi​−cj​)﻿
    Where:
    (3) All other
    K−1K-1K−1﻿ centroids will be 000﻿ except from cjc_jcj​﻿
    (4) Compute the derivative

    To minimize it we put
    ∂Distortion∂cj=0=−2∑i∈OwnedBy(cj)(xi−cj)\frac{\partial \text{Distortion}}{\partial c_j}=0=-2\sum_{i\in OwnedBy(c_j)}(x_i-c_j)∂cj​∂Distortion​=0=−2∑i∈OwnedBy(cj​)​(xi​−cj​)﻿ and compute cjc_jcj​﻿

    cj=1∣numOwnedBy(cj)∣∑i∈OwnedBy(cj)xic_j=\frac{1}{|numOwnedBy(c_j)|}\sum_{i\in OwnedBy(c_j)}x_icj​=∣numOwnedBy(cj​)∣1​∑i∈OwnedBy(cj​)​xi​﻿

There are the 2 steps which are performed alternately until the reach of equilibrium.

Is the termination guaranteed ?

Yes, for 2 reasons:

  1. There is only a finite number of ways to partition N objects into K
    groups.
  1. The algorithm certifies that the new state we reach after a step was never visited before for sure because the distortion is always reduced between steps, so we won’t bounce back to non terminating state.
Are we sure that the best clustering scheme is found ?

Is the ending point either a local or a global (best possible) minimum ?

⇒ WE DON’T KNOW

The procedure works around an equilibrium point, which may be local or global and the algorithm wouldn’t recognize it.

We will find the best solution if we will start from a lucky state.

How should we start ?

We start with a random state and then we try to set the other K−1K-1K−1﻿ values as far as possible.

To increase the possibility of finding the best starting point we could re-run the algorithm and selecting the best ending state.

How can we find the number of clusters?

Its not easy to evaluate correctly KKK﻿ .

We need to try different values and selecting the one which returns the best clustering scheme, based on a quantitative evaluation.

The best KKK﻿ will provide:

  1. The lowest distances inside the clusters
  1. The highest distances between the clusters

Use cases

  1. Data exploration in the beginning
  1. Data discretization un a 1-dimension domain
  1. Base of vector quantization

Complexity

Pros/Cons

✅ Efficient → nearly linear for NNN﻿

🛑 Centroid dependant → not useful if they can’t be computed

🛑 Needs KKK﻿ → difficult to find

🛑 Sensitive to outliers

🛑 Doesn’t deal with noise

🛑 Doesn’t deal with non-convex clusters

Evaluation of a clustering schema

We relate to the result of clustering, not to its technique.

We need to:

  1. Distinguish patterns from random regularities
  1. Find the best number of clusters
  1. Non supervised evaluation
  1. Supervised evaluation
  1. Relative comparison between schemes

Measurement criteria

It’s important to have measurements in order to compare objects. I need to measure the distances/separation between clusters, but it’s not simple since they are made by several points and they can provide several shapes. So it’s not obvious to choose a criteria, for example:

  1. Distances among nearest points
  1. Distances among most distant points
  1. Distances among clusters

I also have to measure the cohesion between the points in the same cluster.

Cohesion

The sum of the proximities between the elements of the cluster and the geometric center.

Based on:

  1. Centroid
  1. Medoid

    Element of the dataset whose average dissimilarity with all the elements of the cluster is minimal. Less sensitive to outliers.

Separation

Distance between two clusters.

Distances may have different definitions but in general we can see the global separation of a clustering scheme as SSB (Sum of Squares Between clusters):

Where ccc﻿ is the global centroid of the entire dataset.

If K=NK=NK=N﻿ we talk about TSS (Total Sum of Squares), which is a global property independently from the clustering scheme

So we can demonstrate an important property:

  • DIM: link between SSE and SSB

    Where:

    (1) Definition of the total sum of squares

    (2) Introducing cluster means cic_ici​﻿ and expressing the squared deviation of each data point from its cluster mean.

    (3) Expanding the squared term

    (4) By definition of cic_ici​﻿ → ∑x∈ki(x−ci)=0\sum_{x \in k_i} (x-c_i)=0∑x∈ki​​(x−ci​)=0﻿

    (5) In the second summation we don’t have xxx﻿ terms, so the summation becomes a multiplication

    (6) SSE is sum of squared errors within each cluster, and SSB is sum of squared deviations between cluster means cic_ici​﻿ and the overall mean ccc﻿ .

Silhouette score of a cluster

If we want to compute the sparsity/cohesion and the separation of clusters, we have to consider the contribution of each object. For example let’s consider the point xix_ixi​﻿, giving 3 clusters to evaluate.

  • Contribution to sparsity from xix_ixi​﻿

    From xix_ixi​﻿ we draw the lines to each of its companions xjx_jxj​﻿ in the same cluster and we compute the average

    aj=averagej,y(xj)=y(xi) dist(xi,xj)a_j=\underset{j, y(x_j)=y(x_i)}{\text{average}} \, dist(x_i, x_j)aj​=j,y(xj​)=y(xi​)average​dist(xi​,xj​)﻿

  • Contribution to separation from xix_ixi​﻿

    From xix_ixi​﻿ we draw the lines to each of the components of other clusters xix_ixi​﻿ and we compute the averages, then we consider the shortest which is the worst case because we want clusters to be well separated.

    bj=mink∈Y,k≠y(xi) (averagej,y(xj)=k dist(xi,xj))b_j=\underset{k \in Y, k\ne y(x_i)}{\text{min}} \, \left( \underset{j, y(x_j)=k}{\text{average}} \, dist(x_i, x_j) \right) bj​=k∈Y,k=y(xi​)min​(j,y(xj​)=kaverage​dist(xi​,xj​))﻿

So the total contribution of xix_ixi​﻿ , also called Silhouette score is:

It’s important to notice that

  • If −1≤si<0-1 \le s_i < 0−1≤si​<0﻿ then there is a dominance of objects in other clusters at a distance smaller than objects of the same cluster.
  • If si=0s_i=0si​=0﻿ then xix_ixi​﻿ is probably a point on the border of a cluster and quite next to another cluster.

It’s also important to notice how good this index is in finding the exact numbers of clusters

As we see, 10 clusters are the optima solution and has the highest silhouette score.

So it is a great indicator but has problem for what concerns complexity which is O(N2)O(N^2)O(N2)﻿ .

Gold Standard

It is a partition of the dataset to be clustered with similarity to the data, defined by yg(.)y_g(.)yg​(.)﻿ .

Despite the similarity, if we apply clustering algorithms to them both, some differences may occure in assigned labels, which depends by algorithms themselves (remapping necessary) and so the focus is on grouping and not labeling.

It serves as a reference or ground truth for evaluating the performance of clustering algorithms, similarly to testing a classifier.

@December 7, 2023

Hierarchical clustering

It is a method of organizing data into a nested structure of clusters, offering both agglomerative (bottom-up) and divisive (top-down) approaches.

  • Agglomerative
    We start from single data as a cluster and, step by step, we
    merge the 2 less separated.
  • Divisive
    We start from the dataset as the cluster and, step by step, the
    cluster with the lowest cohesion is split.

They provide 2 diagrams which represent the same information from 2 different point of view.

Then we’ll cut the creation od diagrams in function of the number of clusters we wants (KKK﻿), so the user has to provide it.

  • The Nested cluster diagram’s diameter is the distance among the most separated objects.
  • The Dendogram’s vertical lines are computed in proportion to total dissimilarity.

Ward’s Method

Used in agglomerative clustering.

If we have to choose if it’s better to perform the merge α\alphaα﻿ or β\betaβ﻿, we have to consider which future merge will increase the least possible the inertia (which will generate the nearest centroid).

So in practice, we compute the original SSE (SSEA  ,  SSEB  ,SSECSSE_{A} \ \ , \ \ SSE_{B} \ \ , SSE_{C}SSEA​  ,  SSEB​  ,SSEC​﻿) and the posteriori ones ( SSEα  ,  SSEβSSE_{\alpha} \ \ , \ \ SSE_{\beta}SSEα​  ,  SSEβ​﻿ ) in order to evaluate what to do.

Then we have to compute the choice:

Single linkage

graph TD
  A(Initialize clusters) --> B(Compute distance matrix between the clusters)
  B --> C{Number of clusters > 1?}
  C -- Yes --> D(Find two clusters with lowest separation)
  D --> E(Merge clusters kr and ks)
  E --> F(Update distance matrix)
  F --> C
  C -- No --> G(Stop - Final clustered structure obtained)

When we talk about updating the distance matrix, we mean that giving krk_rkr​﻿ and ksk_sks​﻿ we delete the rows rr r﻿ and sss﻿, and we do the same for columns.

Then we add a new column and a new row with the distances of the new cluster from the
others. Those are computed by
Dist(kk,k(r+s))=min(Dist(kk,kr),Dist(kk,ks))Dist(k_k, k_{(r+s)})=min(Dist(k_k, k_r), Dist(k_k, k_s))Dist(kk​,k(r+s)​)=min(Dist(kk​,kr​),Dist(kk​,ks​))﻿ and it is valid ∀k∈[1,K]\forall k \in [1,K]∀k∈[1,K]﻿ .

We have also to consider the time/space complexity of the algorithm:

  • Space → O(N2)O(N^2)O(N2)﻿ → storing the distance matrix
  • Time → O(N3)O(N^3)O(N3)﻿

In conclusion:

✅ Dendogram has readable structure

🛑 High complexity → poor scaling

✅ Empirically good

🛑 Local decisions (no global)

Density based clustering

If we observe our dataset we can notice that there will be high–density regions that are separed by low-density regions.

We can compute density in 2 ways:

  1. Grid–based

    We split the hyperspace in regular cells and we count the number of element in each cell to define the density areas.
  1. Object–centered

    For each object we define a hypersphere (circle) by the radius and count the near elements (neighborhood).

DBSCAN

It stands for Density Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise.

We drew a circle of radius ϵ\epsilonϵ﻿ for a border point and for a core point and so we define their neighborhood and …

To define the points we need a threshold (minPointsminPointsminPoints﻿), if a point ha less neighbours than threshold it is a border point, otherwise it is a core point.

We say that a point ppp﻿ is directly density reachable from point qqq﻿ if :

  1. qqq﻿ is core point
  1. qqq﻿ is neighbour of ppp﻿

We say that a point ppp﻿ is density reachable from point qqq﻿ if :

  1. qqq﻿ is core
  1. There is a sequence of core points, from qqq﻿ to ppp﻿, that are one directly density reachable from the previous one.

We say that a point ppp﻿ is density connected to point qqq﻿ if there is a point sss﻿ such that ppp﻿ and qqq﻿ are density reachable from sss﻿ .

Notice that neighborhood and density connection are symmetric while reachability not.

Now we identified 2 parameters we need to set, ϵ\epsilonϵ﻿ and minPointsminPointsminPoints﻿ :

  1. minPoints=2∗DminPoints = 2*DminPoints=2∗D﻿
  1. The best ϵ\epsilonϵ﻿ can be found with a grid search in the area of the change of slope
Notice that if i decrase ϵ\epsilonϵ﻿, then the number of cores decreases beacuse i see less neighbours.
If i increase
minPointsminPointsminPoints﻿, i also increase the noise points.

In conclusion:

✅ Finds clusters of any shape

✅ Is robust w.r.t. noise

🛑 Problems with widely varying densities

Kernel Density Estimation

Family of functions that can be parameterized to better describe the data.

It must be symmetric and monotonically decreasing and usually has a parameter to set the decreasing rate.

Model based clustering

We view the data as a set of observation from a mixture of different probability
distributions. The estimation is usually done using the maximum likelihood.

If the data can be approximated by a single distribution, it’s easy but in general we need to consider mixed distributions and in order to do so, there is the EM algorithm.

EM (Expectation Maximization) algorithm

graph TD
  A(Select initial model parameters) --> B(Repeat until convergence)
  B --> C2(Expectation Step\nCalculate probability for each object belonging to each distribution\n\n)
  C2 --> E(Maximization Step\nFind new estimates of parameters maximizing expected likelihood\n\n)
  E --> B
