@December 13, 2023

Association Rules

It is an expression that describes relationships or associations between sets of items in a dataset.

Where:

  • AAA﻿ is the Antecedent, represents the set of items that precede or occur together.
  • CCC﻿ is the Consequent, represents the set of items that follow or are associated with the antecedent.
Association Rule ≠ Boolean → a rule can be true with some level of truth

σ\sigmaσ﻿({Item1, Item2, Item4}) = Frequency of occurrence of an itemset

Rule Evaluation metrics

If we want to evaluate the transaction {Diaper,Milk}⇒{Beer}\{Diaper,Milk\}\Rightarrow\{Beer\}{Diaper,Milk}⇒{Beer}﻿ :

  • Support (sup) → Fraction of the N transactions that contain both A and C

    sup=σ(Beer,Diaper,Milk)Nsup=\frac{\sigma(Beer,Diaper, Milk)}{N}sup=Nσ(Beer,Diaper,Milk)​﻿

  • Confidence (conf) → Measures how often all the items in C appear in transactions that contain A

    conf=σ(Beer,Diaper,Milk)σ(Diaper,Milk)conf=\frac{\sigma(Beer,Diaper, Milk)}{\sigma(Diaper, Milk)}conf=σ(Diaper,Milk)σ(Beer,Diaper,Milk)​﻿ or conf=sup(A⇒C)sup(C)conf=\frac{sup(A \Rightarrow C)}{sup(C)}conf=sup(C)sup(A⇒C)​﻿

In general we can say that:

  1. If supsupsup﻿ is low → rule may be random
  1. If confconfconf﻿ is low → rule may not be reliable
  1. If supsupsup﻿ is low , confconfconf﻿ is high → intresting

Mining association rules

Our goal with these data is to mine/find all the rules that has a certain confidence and a certain support. That can be by iterating over all the rules computing the metrics and filter them but it will be computationally prohibitive.

So we need to consider another approach (in 2 steps):

  1. Frequent Itemset Generation

    Generate all itemsets whose support is greater than minsup.
  1. Rule Generation

    Generate high confidence rules from each frequent itemset, where each rule is a
    binary partitioning of a frequent itemset.

Frequent Itemset Generation

Given DDD﻿ items, there are 2D2^D2D﻿ possible itemsets.

Brute Force approach

We consider each itemset as a candidate, then we count the support of each candidate by scanning the database and finally we match each transaction against every candidate.

So the complexity seems to be really expensive → O(NWM)O(NWM)O(NWM)﻿

Where:

  • NNN﻿ are the rows → number of transactions
  • WWW﻿ is the maximum transaction width → maximum number of items in a transaction
  • MMM﻿ are the 2D2^D2D﻿ possible itemsets

So we need to reduce MMM﻿, the number of candidates, or NMNMNM﻿, the number of comparisons.

Reducing Number of Candidates

So we have to use more efficient data structures because we don’t need to match every candidate for each transaction and we know it’s not necessary from Apriori principle.

It also means that if an itemset is not frequent, then all its supersets are also non-frequent.

So now we can prune all the subsets of a non-frequent itemset.

Apriori algorithm

Given:

  • CkC_kCk​﻿ candidate itemsets of size kkk﻿
  • LkL_kLk​﻿ frequent itemsets of size kkk﻿, represented as a table with kkk﻿ columns where each row is
    a frequent itemset and in lexicographic order
  • subsetk(c)subset_k(c)subsetk​(c)﻿ set of the subsets of ccc﻿ with kkk﻿ elements

Then:

graph TD;
  A[Initialize with L_1\n\n] -->|Start Loop| B[While L_k is not empty\n\n];
  B -->|1. Candidate Generation| C[Generate C_k+1 from L_k\n\n];
  C -->|2. Count Candidates in Database| D[Increment candidate count in C_k+1 for candidates found in transactions\n\n];
  D -->|3. Prune Candidates| E[Prune C_k+1 by keeping only those with supp ≥ minsup\n\n];
  E -->|4. Update L_k-1\n\n| F[Set L_k-1 to the pruned C_k+1\n\n];
  F -->|5. Decrement k| G[Decrement k by 1];
  G -->|End Loop| B;
  1. Join Step

    We put in CkC_kCk​﻿ all the kkk﻿ items plus one different from the others.

  1. Prune Step

    Each (k+1k+1k+1﻿)-itemset which includes a k-itemset which is not in LkL_kLk​﻿ is deleted from Ck+1C_{k+1}Ck+1​﻿ .

There are come problems with the complexity of the algorithm:

  • Choice of minimum support threshold

    The lower the threshold and the more the frequent itemsets → less pruning, and so increases the complexity.
  • Dimensionality (number of items) of the data set

    We need to memorise the counters for all the candidates and costs increase
  • Size of database
  • Average transaction width

    The number of subsets in a transaction increases with its width and this may increase max length of frequent itemsets and traversals of data structures

Rule Generation

Given a frequent itemset LLL﻿, we need to find all the non empty subsets f∈Lf \in Lf∈L﻿ such that conf(f⇒(L−f))  ≥  confminconf(f\Rightarrow (L-f)) \ \ \ge \ \ conf_{min}conf(f⇒(L−f))  ≥  confmin​﻿

If the size of LLL﻿ is kkk﻿, then there are 2k−22^k-22k−2﻿ candidate rules. So we just consider all the possible rules, except for 2 obvious situations : L⇒∅L\Rightarrow \emptysetL⇒∅﻿ and ∅⇒L\emptyset \Rightarrow L∅⇒L﻿

But we don’t like the exponential exploration, so we need a more efficient way.

Confidence of rules generated from the same itemset is anti-monotone w.r.t. the number of items on the RHS of the rule (not anti-monotone in general)
  • Example

    conf(ABC⇒D)≥conf(AB⇒CD)≥conf(A⇒BCD)\text{conf}(ABC \Rightarrow D) \geq \text{conf}(AB \Rightarrow CD) \geq \text{conf}(A \Rightarrow BCD)conf(ABC⇒D)≥conf(AB⇒CD)≥conf(A⇒BCD)﻿

So the candidate rule is generated by merging two rules that share the same prefix in the rule consequent: join(CD⇒AB,BD⇒AC)=(D⇒ABC)\text{join}(CD \Rightarrow AB, BD \Rightarrow AC) = (D \Rightarrow ABC)join(CD⇒AB,BD⇒AC)=(D⇒ABC)﻿

Pattern Evaluation

We want to evaluate the interestingness of a rule. Our algorithms can produce all the right rules but many of them are uninteresting or redundant and so we want to filter them.

Given a rule X⇒YX \Rightarrow YX⇒Y﻿, we draw a contingecy table:

Some of the statistical measures are:

  • Lift
    • If lift(X⇒Y)=1lift(X \Rightarrow Y)=1lift(X⇒Y)=1﻿ → XXX﻿ and YYY﻿ are independent
    • If lift(X⇒Y)>1lift(X \Rightarrow Y)>1lift(X⇒Y)>1﻿ → XXX﻿ and YYY﻿ are positively correlated
    • If lift(X⇒Y)>1lift(X \Rightarrow Y)>1lift(X⇒Y)>1﻿ → XXX﻿ and YYY﻿ are negatively correlated
    It is the ratio of true cases w.r.t. independence

    Insensitive to rule direction

  • Leverage
    • If leve(X⇒Y)=0leve(X \Rightarrow Y)=0leve(X⇒Y)=0﻿ → XXX﻿ and YYY﻿ are independent
    • If leve(X⇒Y)>0leve(X \Rightarrow Y)>0leve(X⇒Y)>0﻿ → XXX﻿ and YYY﻿ are positively correlated
    • If leve(X⇒Y)>0leve(X \Rightarrow Y)>0leve(X⇒Y)>0﻿ → XXX﻿ and YYY﻿ are negatively correlated
    It is the number of additional cases w.r.t. independence

    Insensitive to rule direction

  • Conviction
    • If conv(X⇒Y)→∞conv(X \Rightarrow Y) \rightarrow \infinconv(X⇒Y)→∞﻿ then the rule is always true
    It is the ratio of the expected frequency that X occurs without Y (the frequency that the rule makes an incorrect prediction) if X and Y were independent divided by the observed frequency of incorrect predictions

    Sensitive to rule direction

Observations

Now we can make important observations about measures:

  • sup  >>sup \ \ >>sup  >>﻿ → rule applies to >> records
  • conf>>conf >> conf>>﻿ → chance that the rule is true for some record >>
  • lift  >>lift \ \ >>lift  >>﻿ → chance that the rule is just a coincidence <<
  • conv>>conv >>conv>>﻿ → rule is violated << frequently than if the X and Y were independent.

In a contingency table we would observe:

  • A high confidence rule can have small lift, if both sides are very frequent
  • A low confidence rule can have high lift, if both sides are very infrequent

Multidimensional association rules

We may have datasets that provide multidimensional data and this will change our association rules from transactions to tuples.

Anyway we can exchange a transaction to a tuple quite well:

Multilevel Association Rules

In order to find the right tradeoff between general and detailed reasoning, it’s common to organise the items into a hierarchy of concepts (easily coded and easy level selection).

The more we generalize the rule and the more its support increases and viceversa.
